Ideally, we would like two vectors of the same length: one representing `Year` and one representing `Population`. Today, we'll discuss how to do this in both **base R** and the **tidyverse**. ## `pivot_longer()` and `pivot_wider()` The `pivot_longer()` and `pivot_wider()` functions are useful for reshaping data: `pivot_longer()` "lengthens" datasets and `pivot_wider()` does the opposite. They are challenging to use because you need to have a clear vision of the data frame you want, not because they are complicated in R. ## Example: `pivot_longer()` {.smaller} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} relig_income ``` ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}

`US_pop[1, 8:19]` is a tibble, and we need a numeric. . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plot_dat <- data.frame( Year = 2010:2020, Population = as.numeric(US_pop[1, 8:19]) ) ``` ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in data.frame(Year = 2010:2020, Population = as.numeric(US_pop[1, : arguments imply differing number of rows: 11, 12 ``` ::: ::: ## National population data Now what? `US_pop` has an extra column `POPESTIMATE042020` which we need to remove. . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # base R plot_dat <- data.frame( Year = 2010:2020, Population = as.numeric(US_pop[, c(8:17, 19)]) ) head(plot_dat) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Year Population 1 2010 309327143 2 2011 311583481 3 2012 313877662 4 2013 316059947 5 2014 318386329 6 2015 320738994 ``` ::: ::: ## National population data Finally, we can use the `plot` function to get our desired visualization: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plot(plot_dat$Year, plot_dat$Population) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](09_merging-data_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-29-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Approach 2: Tidyverse Now let's see how we might approach the same task in the tidyverse. Our strategy will be to "tidy" the data so we have one row for each observation and one column for each observation. First, let's remove the unnecessary column using the `select()` function. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} US_pop |> select(-POPESTIMATE042020) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}

010 0 0 00 United States 308745538 308758105 309327143 311583481 313877662 316059947 318386329 320738994 323071755 325122128 326838199 328329953 329484123

`inner_join(x, y, by = "key")`: match observations only when exact keys are equal - `left_join(x, y, by = "key")`: keep all observations in `x`, match observations in `y` by keys, `NA` otherwise - `right_join(x, y, by = "key")`: keep all observations in `y`, match observations in `x` by keys, `NA` otherwise - `outer_join(x, y, by = "key")`: keep all observations in `x` and `y`, match keys where possible, `NA` otherwise Usually, `left_join()` will suffice. ## Example: Band members ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) band_members ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 2 name band 1 Mick Stones 2 John Beatles 3 Paul Beatles ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} band_instruments ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 2 name plays 1 John guitar 2 Paul bass 3 Keith guitar ``` ::: ::: ## Example: Band members ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} band_members |> inner_join(band_instruments) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 3 name band plays 1 John Beatles guitar 2 Paul Beatles bass ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} band_members |> left_join(band_instruments) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 3 name band plays 1 Mick Stones 2 John Beatles guitar 3 Paul Beatles bass ``` ::: ::: ## Example: Band members ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} band_members |> right_join(band_instruments) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 3 name band plays 1 John Beatles guitar 2 Paul Beatles bass 3 Keith guitar ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} band_members |> full_join(band_instruments) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 3 name band plays 1 Mick Stones 2 John Beatles guitar 3 Paul Beatles bass 4 Keith guitar ``` ::: ::: ## Example: Band members ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # To suppress the message about joining variables, supply `by` band_members |> inner_join(band_instruments, by = join_by(name)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 3 name band plays 1 John Beatles guitar 2 Paul Beatles bass ``` ::: ::: ## Inner join vs. outer join Images courtesy of Hadley Wickham. [(Link)](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/relational-data.html) ## Base R ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # inner join merge(band_members, band_instruments, by.x = "name", by.y = "name") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` name band plays 1 John Beatles guitar 2 Paul Beatles bass ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # outer join merge(band_members, band_instruments, by.x = "name", by.y = "name", all = T) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` name band plays 1 John Beatles guitar 2 Keith guitar 3 Mick Stones 4 Paul Beatles bass ``` ::: ::: ## Base R ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # left join merge(band_members, band_instruments, by.x = "name", by.y = "name", all.x = T) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` name band plays 1 John Beatles guitar 2 Mick Stones 3 Paul Beatles bass ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # right join merge(band_members, band_instruments, by.x = "name", by.y = "name", all.y = T) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` name band plays 1 John Beatles guitar 2 Keith guitar 3 Paul Beatles bass ``` ::: ::: ## Data manipulation cheatsheet - `filter()` subset rows - `select()` subset columns, use with `contains()`, `starts_with()`, `ends_with()`, ... - `mutate()` create columns - `group_by()`, `summarize()`, `count()` group and summarize groups - `rename()` rename columns - `pivot_longer()`, `pivot_wider()` reshape data - `inner_join()`, `left_join()`, `right_join()`, `outer_join()` combine data (like SQL) [Much, much more! (Click me for a cheat sheet)](https://rstudio.com/resources/cheatsheets/) ## Exploratory data analysis Exploratory data analysis is the process of learning about a dataset by visualizing, summarizing, and transforming it. By now we've seen most of the skills you need to carry out exploratory data analysis (EDA). As Wickham, etinkaya-Rundel, and Grolemund put it, the cycle of EDA looks something like this: 1. Generate questions about your data. 2. Explore your questions by visualizing, transforming, and modelling your data. 3. Use your findings to refine your questions and generate new questions. You can read their walkthrough of the EDA process [here](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/eda). ## Example: World Bank Inflation Data The World Bank provides historical data on inflation in countries around the world [here](https://www.worldbank.org/en/research/brief/inflation-database). In particular, let's explore the annual consumer price inflation data for the US. . . . <script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
